title: Basic Structure of Computer
content:
Covers the main components of a computer including the CPU, motherboard, and power supply. 

These components are essential for the basic functioning of the computer.

title: Computer Peripherals
content:
Peripheral devices extend the functionality of a computer. 

Examples include the mouse, keyboard, and monitor, which allow interaction with the system.

title: Types of Computer Peripherals
content:
Computer peripherals are categorized based on their functions: 

1. Input devices (mouse, microphone) 

2. Output devices (monitor, speaker) 

3. Input/Output and storage devices (RAM, DVD-ROM)

title: Input Devices
content:
Input devices send data to the computer for processing. 

Examples include the mouse, which controls the cursor, and the microphone, which inputs audio data.

title: Output Devices
content:
Output devices receive data from the computer and display or output information. 

Examples include monitors for graphical display and speakers for audio output.

title: Memory Overview
content:
Memory stores data and instructions temporarily (RAM) or permanently (ROM, hard drives). 

Memory is divided into primary memory (RAM, ROM) and secondary storage (SSDs, HDDs).

title: Random Access Memory (RAM)
content:
RAM is volatile memory that stores data temporarily while programs are running. 

It is further classified into SRAM (Static RAM) and DRAM (Dynamic RAM).

title: Read Only Memory (ROM)
content:
ROM is non-volatile memory that stores essential instructions for the computer's boot process. 

Types include PROM, EPROM, and EEPROM, which vary in how data can be written or erased.

title: Secondary Storage Devices
content:
Secondary storage devices, such as SSDs and HDDs, provide long-term storage for data and programs. 

They are used for storing backups, operating systems, and applications.

title: System Configuration
content:
System configuration refers to the hardware, software, and processes that define how a computer functions. 

It includes details like installed devices, operating systems, and system settings.

title: Hard Disk Drives (HDD)
content:
HDDs use spinning magnetic platters to store data. 

They are slower than SSDs but offer large storage capacities at a lower cost.

title: Solid-State Drives (SSD)
content:
SSDs use flash memory with no moving parts, making them faster and more reliable than HDDs. 

They are ideal for tasks that require quick data access, such as gaming and video editing.

title: Processor and Threads
content:
The processor (CPU) is responsible for executing instructions. 

Threads allow the processor to handle multiple tasks simultaneously, improving multitasking performance.

title: BIOS Configuration
content:
BIOS is firmware stored on ROM that initializes and tests hardware during the boot process. 

It ensures the system is ready to load the operating system.

title: PC Connection Interfaces
content:
Various interfaces are used to connect peripherals and devices to a computer, such as USB, HDMI, and SATA. 

These interfaces allow for data transfer and device communication.

title: RAID
content:
RAID (Redundant Array of Independent Disks) uses multiple disks to improve storage performance and provide fault tolerance. 

Different RAID configurations offer varying levels of speed and reliability.

title: Graphics Processing Unit (GPU)
content:
GPUs are specialized processors for rendering graphics and video. 

They are essential for tasks like gaming, content creation, and AI computations.

title: Computer Languages
content:
Computer languages include: 

1. Machine language (binary code) 

2. Assembly language (low-level code) 

3. High-level languages like C and FORTRAN, which are more human-readable.

title: Steps in Program Development
content:
The program development process includes: 

1. Writing the code 

2. Compiling the code into machine language 

3. Assembling the code 

4. Linking the program for execution 

5. Loading the program into memory for execution.

title: Compiler
content:
A compiler translates high-level programming languages into machine code that the computer can execute. 

It reads the entire program at once, generating object code or an executable file.

title: Interpreter
content:
An interpreter executes high-level language code line by line, translating each statement as it goes. 

It is typically used for scripting languages but is slower than a compiler.

title: Assembler
content:
An assembler converts assembly language code into machine code. 

It produces object files, which are then linked to create an executable program.
